content.description: Researchers examined the effect of industrialization and increased pollution (soot) in London on the coloration in a single species of moths. Birds prey on the moths that are easily visible on trees. The researchers observed moths on tree trunks and recorded their body color. The percentage of moths with light colored bodies and the percentage of moths with dark bodies is shown on the graph above.
content.question: In the 1970s, the amount of industrial pollution decreased and the trees began to return to their preindustrial appearance. Which of the following graphs best demonstrates the change in the frequencies of light-colored moths and dark-colored moths in the population from 1950 to 2000? The dark-colored moths are represented with a solid line and the light-colored moths are represented with a dashed line.

choices.label: The figure presents the graph of two curves in the coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled Years, and the years 1950 and 2000 are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled Percentage of Moths Captured, and the numbers 0 through 100, in increments of 10, are indicated. The dark-colored moths are represented by the first curve, and the light-colored moths are represented by the second curve. The curve representing dark-colored moths is a straight horizontal line that passes through 95 percent in 1950, and 95 percent in 2000. The curve representing light-colored moths begins at approximately 4 percent in 1940, moves downward and to the right until it reaches approximately 1 percent in 150. It then remains relatively steady until it reaches 3 percent in 1975. The curve then moves steeply upward, intersecting the first curve at 95 percent in 2005, and then continues upward.

The figure presents the graph of two curves in the coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled Years, and the years 1950 and 2000 are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled Percentage of Moths Captured, and the numbers 0 through 100, in increments of 10, are indicated. The dark-colored moths are represented by the first curve, and the light-colored moths are represented by the second curve. The curve representing dark-colored moths is a straight horizontal line that passes through 95 percent in 1950, and 95 percent in 2000. The curve representing light-colored moths is a straight horizontal line that passes through 5 percent in 1950, and 5 percent in 2000.

The figure presents the graph of two curves in the coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled Years, and the years 1950 and 2000 are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled Percentage of Moths Captured, and the numbers 0 through 100, in increments of 10, are indicated. The dark-colored moths are represented by the first curve, and the light-colored moths are represented by the second curve. The curve representing dark-colored moths begins at 96 percent in 1940, moves gradually upward until it reaches 99 percent in 1950. Then, it remains relatively steady until it reaches 97 percent in 1975. The curve then begins to move downward and to the right, passing through 15 percent, at 2000. It continues downward until it ends. The curve representing light-colored moths begins at approximately 4 percent in 1940, moves gradually downward until it reaches 1 percent in 1950. Then, it remains relatively steady until it reaches 3 percent in 1975. The curve then begins to move upward and to the right, intersecting the first curve at 55 percent in 1990. It continues upward, passing through 85 percent in 2000. It continues downward until it ends.

The figure presents the graph of two curves in the coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled Years, and the years 1950 and 2000 are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled Percentage of Moths Captured, and the numbers 0 through 100, in increments of 10, are indicated. The dark-colored moths are represented by the first curve, and the light-colored moths are represented by the second curve. The two curves move erratically, except that overall their shapes appear to be similar but inverted. The curve representing dark-colored moths begins at 99 percent in 1940. Between 1940 and 1970, the curve spans between 82 and 99 percent. Between 1970 and 2000, the curve spans between 73 and 95 percent. It ends at 88 percent in 2005. The curve representing light-colored moths begins at 1 percent in 1940. Between 1940 and 1970, the curve spans between 1 and 22 percent. Between 1970 and 2000, the curve spans between 5 and 27 percent. It ends at 6 percent in 2005.

content.answer: The figure presents the graph of two curves in the coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled Years, and the years 1950 and 2000 are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled Percentage of Moths Captured, and the numbers 0 through 100, in increments of 10, are indicated. The dark-colored moths are represented by the first curve, and the light-colored moths are represented by the second curve. The curve representing dark-colored moths begins at 96 percent in 1940, moves gradually upward until it reaches 99 percent in 1950. Then, it remains relatively steady until it reaches 97 percent in 1975. The curve then begins to move downward and to the right, passing through 15 percent, at 2000. It continues downward until it ends. The curve representing light-colored moths begins at approximately 4 percent in 1940, moves gradually downward until it reaches 1 percent in 1950. Then, it remains relatively steady until it reaches 3 percent in 1975. The curve then begins to move upward and to the right, intersecting the first curve at 55 percent in 1990. It continues upward, passing through 85 percent in 2000. It continues downward until it ends.

skill.text: Skill 5.B: Describe relationships among variables in data represented.
